The "module5" logo, featuring a purple rectangle with white text, is displayed against a white background..  The image features a purple rectangular sign with the text "module5" prominently displayed in white letters. The sign is positioned against a white background, making the purple color stand out.

A blue collared shirt with 2 sleeves, size L, blue buttons, and a date-like appearance is shown, accompanied by a list of questions for verification..  The image presents a blue dress shirt with a collar, long sleeves, and buttons. It is shown in a folded state, and the shirt appears to be made of a cotton fabric. The shirt is displayed against a white background, and there are five questions posed to the viewer, each asking about the shirt's attributes. The questions include: "2 sleeves?", "Is it size L?", "Is it blue?", "Are any buttons missing?", "Does it fit?", "Is it comfortable to drive in?", "Does the colour match my eyes?", "Can I afford it?", "Is it good quality?", and "Will my date like it?".

A cartoon man in a white shirt and blue tie evaluates software products, with a checklist of verification and validation techniques..  A cartoon man in a suit and tie, a computer monitor, and a checklist

A spiral diagram illustrates the stages of System Testing, Validation testing, Integration testing, Unit testing, Code, Design, Requirements, and System engineering..  The image presents a spiral diagram illustrating the different stages of software development, from System engineering to Code. The spiral is divided into concentric circles, each representing a specific stage. The stages are System testing, Validation testing, Integration testing, Unit testing, Code, Design requirements, System engineering. A line is drawn through the center of the spiral, indicating the progression from System engineering to Code.

A software testing hierarchy, including Manual Testing, Automation Testing, Functional Testing, Non-Functional Testing, Usability Testing, Compatibility Testing, Incremental Testing, Non-Incremental Testing, Load Testing, Stress Testing, Scalability Testing, Stability Testing, and Top-down Testing, is presented in a tree-like structure..  The image presents a hierarchical structure of software testing types, categorized into Manual Testing, Automation Testing, Functional Testing, Non-Functional Testing, System Testing, Performance Testing, Usability Testing, Compatibility Testing, Load Testing, Stress Testing, Scalability Testing, Stability Testing, Incremental Testing, Non-Incremental Testing, Top-down Testing, Bottom-up Testing, White Box, Black Box, Grey Box, Integration Testing, System Testing, Performance Testing, Usability Testing, Compatibility Testing, Load Testing, Stress Testing, Scalability Testing, Stability Testing

A feedback loop connects a developer to a tester or developer, with a laptop displaying code and a magnifying glass for review..  The image shows a feedback loop between a developer and a tester or developer. The developer is shown with a laptop, while the tester is represented by a magnifying glass. The feedback loop indicates that the developer has written code and requested a review. The tester then reviews the code and provides feedback. The feedback loop is visually represented by arrows connecting the developer to the tester.

Three boxes labeled "Black Box Testing", "White Box Testing", and "Grey Box Testing" are shown with a plus sign, indicating internal functionality is unknown..  The image presents a visual representation of three different testing methods: Black Box Testing, White Box Testing, and Grey Box Testing. Each method is represented by a box, with the boxes being colored and labeled accordingly.

The Black Box Testing method is shown with a dark blue box, indicating that the internal functionality is unknown. The White Box Testing method is represented with a white box, indicating that internal functionality is known. The Grey Box Testing method is shown with a grey box, indicating that internal functionality is partially known.

The boxes are arranged in a row, with the addition of a plus sign (+) between them, symbolizing the sum of the three testing methods. The text "Internal functionality is unknown" is present at the bottom of the image, providing context for each testing method.

Three diamond-shaped boxes labeled "White box Testing," "Black box Testing," and "Gray box Testing" are arranged in a triangular formation, each with a unique color and text..  The image presents a visual representation of the types of manual testing. It features three distinct types of testing: White box testing, Black box testing, and Gray box testing. Each type of testing is represented by a unique color: green, orange, and blue. The text "Types of Manual Testing" is displayed at the top of the image, clearly indicating the different types of testing being discussed.

A blue cube labeled "Application Code" with a network diagram and two pink speech bubbles labeled "Test Case Input" and "Test Case Output" is shown..  The image shows a blue box labeled "Application Code" with a flowchart diagram on its front. The flowchart illustrates the process of testing a software application, including input, test case input, test case output, and the application code itself. The flowchart includes various nodes, such as hexagons, circles, and squares, which represent different stages or components of the testing process. Arrows indicate the direction of the flow, showing the progression of the testing process. The flowchart is accompanied by two speech bubbles, one labeled "Test Case Input" and the other "Test Case Output," indicating the inputs and outputs of the testing process.

A black cardboard box with a white label and a black stripe is tilted on a white background, accompanied by the text "Black box - we do not know anything.".  The image shows a black box with a white label on it. The box is sitting on a white surface, and there is a shadow cast by the box. The text "Black box â€“ we do not know anything" is written in black at the bottom of the image.
The QA tester logo, featuring the letters "QA" in black against a white background, is centered and bold..  The image contains the text "QA testers" in a sans-serif font.

A black cube labeled "Black Box Testing" is surrounded by a person with question marks, indicating a testing process..  The image presents a diagram illustrating the Black Box Testing process. A person is shown with question marks above their head, suggesting confusion or uncertainty. The person is standing in front of a black box, which is labeled "Black Box Testing." The diagram also includes an arrow pointing to the left, labeled "Input," and an arrow pointing to the right, labeled "Output." This visual representation highlights the input and output stages of the testing process.

A mobile number entry form displays a light blue box for entering a ten-digit mobile number, with "Enter Ten Digit Mobile Number" and "Submit" buttons..  The image shows a mobile number entry form with a purple background. The form has a light blue box in the center, which contains the instruction "Enter Ten Digit Mobile Number." There are two buttons on either side of the box: a "Submit" button on the right and a "Back" button on the left.

A table displays the results of a test case, categorizing it as invalid (digits >-11), invalid (digits <-9), valid (digits =10), and valid (digits =10)..  The image shows a table with four columns labeled "INVALID," "INVALID," "VALID," and "VALID." Each column represents a different number of test cases: 1, 2, 3, and 4. The table displays the number of test cases for each invalid case: 9384726219, 984543985, 9991456234, and 9893451483. The "VALID" column shows the number of test cases for each valid case: 10, 9, and 88,345,148, respectively.

A timeline shows the progression of a project, with "Invalid partition" at $78, "Valid partition" at $140, "Valid partition (20%)" at $370, and "Valid partition (30%)" at $530..  The image presents a timeline of four stages in a process, labeled as "Invalid partition," "Valid partition (10%), Valid partition (20%), and Valid partition (30%)." Each stage is represented by a red rectangle with a corresponding dollar amount. The stages are:

1. Invalid partition: $78
2. Invalid partition (10%)
3. Valid partition (20%)
4. Valid partition (30%)

An orange line labeled "a" connects two orange circles labeled "x(min)" and "x(max)", with an arrow labeled "b" pointing to the right..  The image shows a diagram with a horizontal line labeled "x" and two circles labeled "a" and "b." The line "x" is connected to the two circles, and the circles are positioned at the ends of the line. The line "x" is labeled "b," indicating a transition or connection between the two circles. The diagram appears to represent a sequence or progression, with the circles labeled "a" and "b" and the line "x" representing a transition or connection point.

A table displays the results of three password conditions: Email (condition1), Password (condition2), and Expected Result (Action)..  The image shows a table with three columns: Email (condition1), Password (condition2), and Expected Result (Action). Each column has a T for True, F for False, and F for Incorrect email. The table is organized with rows for each condition, and the expected result is displayed in the last column.

A transition diagram illustrates a state change process, with input and output states, an event, and a transition arrow indicating a change from State 1 to State 2..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating a transition process. It shows two states, State 1 and State 2, with an event occurring between them. The event is represented by a blue rectangle labeled "Event Action." The flowchart also includes an input and output, with an oval labeled "Transition" at the top. The event occurs between the two states, and the transition is represented by an arrow pointing from State 1 to State 2.

A process diagram illustrates a sequence of events: incorrect PIN, incorrect attempt, incorrect attempt, and successful attempt, leading to account locked..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of unlocking an account. It has three main sections: Start, Attempt Failed, and Success. The Start section shows a pin labeled "Start," indicating the beginning of the process. The Attempt Failed section shows a pin labeled "1st Attempt Failed," indicating a failed attempt. The Success section shows a pin labeled "Success," indicating a successful unlocking of the account. The Account Locked section shows a pin labeled "Account Locked," indicating that the account has been successfully unlocked.

A login screen with a valid credentials check and error message is shown, transitioning to a welcome screen with a login screen and logout button..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the login process. It consists of three states: State 1 (Login Screen), State 2 (Logout), and State 3 (Error Message). The login screen is represented by a blue rectangle labeled "Login Screen," and the login process involves entering credentials. The error message is displayed in a blue rectangle labeled "Error Message." The login screen and the login process are connected to the error message, indicating that the login process may fail due to an error.

A 3x3 grid displays twelve squares, each representing a different quality: Security, Availability, Efficiency, Integrity, Reliability, Survivability, Usability, Flexibility, Scalability, Reusability, Interoperability, and Portability..  The image presents a grid of twelve squares, each containing a different characteristic or quality. The squares are arranged in a 4x3 grid, with each row representing a different quality: Security, Availability, Efficiency, Integrity, Reliability, Survivability, Usability, Flexibility, Scalability, Reusability, Interoperability, and Portability.

A 3D diagram illustrates the levels of testing, from Unit Testing to System Testing, with acceptance testing at the final stage..  The image presents a step-by-step process of levels of testing, labeled as 1, 2, 3, and 4. It shows a three-dimensional pyramid shape with each level representing a different stage of testing. The stages are: Unit Testing, Integration Testing, System Testing, and Acceptance Testing. The pyramid structure visually represents the progression of testing levels, emphasizing the importance of each stage in ensuring the quality and reliability of the final system.

A pyramid-shaped diagram illustrates the stages of software development, from acceptance testing to end user testing, with integration testing and end user testing at the top..  The image presents a pyramid-shaped diagram illustrating the different stages of software testing. The pyramid is divided into four levels, each representing a specific testing stage: Acceptance Testing, System Testing, Integration Testing, and End User Testing.

The pyramid is divided into four sections, each representing a different testing stage. The topmost section is labeled "End User Testing," indicating the final stage of testing before the software is released to the public. The bottom section is labeled "Dev," signifying the development stage.

The pyramid visually represents the sequential process of software testing, starting with acceptance testing and progressing to integration testing, followed by end user testing, and finally to the development stage. Arrows indicate the flow of testing from one stage to the next.

A unit testing setup for a banking application, with a server, module, and transaction buttons, and a table for account transfer and cancellation..  The image contains a diagram illustrating unit testing, specifically focusing on the transfer and cancellation buttons. It shows a server with three account numbers: M1, M2, and M3. The server has a "Account Transfer" module, which includes a "Module" component with a "Transfer" button. The transfer button allows users to transfer funds between accounts. The cancellation button allows users to cancel transactions. The transfer button has a description field for entering valid transfer values, valid transfer values, and correct amount. The cancellation button has a description field for entering the value of the transfer button, the amount, and ensuring the transaction is clear. The transfer button has a description field for entering the transfer value, valid transfer values, and correct amount. The cancellation button has a description field for entering the value of the cancel button, the amount, and ensuring the transaction is clear.

Three blue spheres labeled "Module A", "Module B", and "Module C" are arranged in a triangular formation, with "Module A" and "Module B" under "Tested in Unit Testing" and "Module C" under "Under Integration Testing"..  The image presents a visual representation of integration testing, specifically focusing on modules A, B, and C. There are three large, glossy, three-dimensional circles surrounding the modules. Each circle is labeled with the name of the module: Module A, Module B, and Module C. The circles are arranged in a triangular formation, with Module A at the top, Module B in the middle, and Module C at the bottom.

The text "Tested in Unit Testing" is written above the circles, indicating the purpose of the testing process. The image also includes the phrase "Under Integration Testing," highlighting the stage of the testing process.

A green flowchart illustrates a software testing process, from setup to execution, with stages for setup, generation, execution, and reporting..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of setting up a test environment, generating test cases, executing test cases, and reporting defects. The flowchart is divided into eight distinct sections, each representing a different step in the process. The sections are labeled as Setup Test Environment, Generate Test Cases, Generate Testing Data, Execute Test Cases, Execute Test Cases Data, Regression Testing, Defect Reporting. The flowchart uses green boxes to visually represent the different stages and processes involved in the test environment setup, generation of test cases, execution of test cases, and reporting of defects.

A software acceptance test results in a failed acceptance test, causing a software application to be rejected and a product not ready for customer use..  The image shows a software acceptance test process. It depicts a person testing software applications, with a red explosion-shaped cloud labeled "Acceptance Test" indicating that the software application has been accepted. There are three boxes: one labeled "Software Application," one labeled "Software Application Passed," and another labeled "Software Application Failed."

There are also two people in the image. One person is labeled "User," and the other is labeled "Passed." A green checkmark is placed next to the "Software Application Passed" box, indicating that the software application is ready for customer use. A red "X" is placed next to the "Software Application Failed" box, indicating that the software application has not been accepted.

A software development lifecycle process, from Unit Testing to User Acceptance Testing, with QA Team and End-users, is depicted in a flowchart..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating the process of unit testing, integration testing, system testing, user acceptance testing, and UAT sign-off. It shows the sequence of steps, from Unit Testing to Production Rollout, with end-users, QA Team, and Dev Team involved in the process. The flowchart highlights the collaboration between different teams and the different phases of testing.

A person works on a laptop, surrounded by tools, frameworks, and a software development result, with a computer monitor displaying a software development process..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of creating a software project. The flowchart has three main sections: Tools, Framework, and Software.

In the Tools section, there is a person working on a laptop, indicating the use of tools and software development. The Framework section shows a laptop with a screen displaying a software project, indicating the software development process. The Software section shows a computer monitor with a software project displayed, indicating the result of the software development.

The flowchart highlights the sequential steps involved in creating a software project, from script to result.

A flowchart illustrates the stages of regression testing, including Retest, Regression, Prioritization, and All, with a recycling symbol and checkmarks for each stage..  The image presents a flowchart illustrating the process of regression testing. It is divided into three sections: Retest All, Regression Test Selection, and Prioritization of Test Cases.

In the Retest All section, there is a recycling symbol, indicating that the testing process is environmentally friendly. The recycling symbol is green, and the text "Retest All" is written below it.

The Regression Test Selection section shows a checklist with checkmarks, indicating that the testing process is being performed. The checklist includes four checkboxes, with two checkmarks and one unchecked box.

The Prioritization of Test Cases section shows a list of test cases, with arrows pointing to the right, indicating that the testing process is prioritized. The text "Prioritization of Test Cases" is written below the checklist.

A flowchart illustrates the three types of regression testing: Unit Regression, Regional Regression, and Full Regression..  The image presents a visual representation of three types of regression testing: Unit Regression, Regional Regression, and Full Regression. Each type of regression testing is represented by a separate colored circle, with the circles arranged in a descending order of complexity. The circles are labeled with the type of regression testing, and the text above them clearly states the type of regression testing. The circles are positioned against a black background, creating a visually distinct and organized presentation of the three types of regression testing.

A dark blue window displays a white box with "Search field(1-35 characters)" and two buttons: "SEARCH" and "CANCEL"..  The image shows a dark blue background with a white rectangular box containing the text "(Search field)1-35 characters". Below the box, there are two buttons: one labeled "SEARCH" in green and the other labeled "CANCEL" in red. The text "Build 1-B002" is displayed at the bottom of the image.

A brown box with a white label displays "SEARCH (Search field) 1-15 characters" and two buttons: "SEARCH" and "CANCEL"..  The image shows a button with two options: "SEARCH" and "CANCEL." The button is labeled as "Build 1-B001." The text above the button states "(Search field)1-15 characters." The button has a brown background, and the text is black.

A light blue square divided into four quadrants, labeled "Build 1-B001", "Module A", "Module B", and "Module C", with black squares indicating impact areas and Modification in B002..  The image shows a square-shaped structure with four distinct modules labeled A, B, C, and D. Each module is represented by a white square with a black rectangle in the center. The modules are arranged in a grid-like pattern, with Module A positioned in the top left corner, Module B in the top right corner, Module C in the bottom left corner, and Module D in the bottom right corner.

There are also annotations in the image. The top left corner indicates "Build 1-B001," suggesting the module A is being built. The top right corner shows "Modification in B002," indicating that Module B is being modified. The bottom left corner shows "Impact Areas," indicating the areas where modifications are being made. The bottom right corner shows "Modification in B002," indicating the modification is being made in Module B.

A pie chart illustrates the impact of a new feature, with 70% of users not affected and 20% experiencing a positive impact..  The image presents a pie chart divided into three sections, each representing a different level of impact analysis. The sections are labeled "New Feature," "Impact Analysis," and "Not Affected." The pie chart shows the percentage of users who experienced each level of impact analysis. The New Feature section has the largest percentage of users (70%), followed by Impact Analysis (20%), and the Not Affected section (20%).

A blue box labeled "Test Strategy" is connected to an orange box labeled "Test Plan" via a plus sign, with a question about test logistics..  The image contains three key visual elements: a blue box labeled "Test Strategy," a blue box labeled "Test Logistics," and an orange box labeled "Test Plan." The blue box is labeled "Test Strategy" and the orange box is labeled "Test Plan." The blue box contains the text "Test Strategy is Approach i.e. What, Why, When & How in Testing," while the orange box contains the text "Test Logistics - Who in Testing?"

A blue flowchart illustrates the process of designing a product, starting with analyzing the product, followed by planning, resource planning, defining test criteria, scheduling, estimation, and determining test deliverables..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating a process for planning a test environment. The steps include:

1. Analyze the product
2. Design Test Strategy
3. Define Test Objectives
4. Define Test Criteria
5. Resource Planning
6. Plan Test Environment
7. Schedule & Estimation
8. Determine Test Deliverables

Four blue boxes on a white background outline a step-by-step process: "Pick One Or More Product Ideas", "Select Metrics", "Send Survey", and "Analyze Results"..  The image contains four distinct steps, each represented by a blue box with a white outline. The steps are numbered 01, 02, 03, and 04. Each step has a title and a corresponding icon or diagram. Step 01 shows a chart with a checkmark, step 02 displays a bar graph, step 03 shows a paper airplane, and step 04 shows a magnifying glass.

A cyclical process of product development, from interview to review, is illustrated with three stages: interview, review, and review, with a final stage of product walkthrough..  The image shows a flowchart illustrating the process of product development. It depicts three stages: Interview, Review, and Perform. The stages are interconnected, with arrows indicating the progression from interviewing a client to reviewing the product and project documentation. The flowchart highlights the importance of each stage in the product development process.

A blue and white flowchart illustrates the testing process, starting with "Testing Scope" and progressing through "Verify Types of Testing," "Problems and Challenges," and "Test Logistics.".  The image presents a step-by-step process of testing a product or service. The steps are numbered 01, 02, 03, and 04. Each step is represented by a circle, and the text within the circles describes the next stage in the testing process.

The first step is "Testing Scope," which involves defining the scope of the testing, including the objectives, target audience, and key performance indicators. The second step is "Verify Types of Testing," which focuses on verifying the types of testing being conducted to ensure they align with the product's purpose and requirements. The third step is "Problems and Challenges," which highlights the issues and obstacles encountered during testing, such as technical, operational, or quality-related problems. The fourth step is "Test Logistics," which involves coordinating the logistics of the testing process, including scheduling, resources, and communication.

A test environment, human resources, and test specs are combined to create a ready-to-test scenario..  The image shows a process of preparing for a test. It includes a folder labeled "Test specs and Requirement document," a group of people in a blue figure, a software package icon, and a pink box with the text "Ready to Test."

A blue and white infographic presents four steps in a scientific research process: Verify Models, Validate Features, Maintain Consistency, and Carry Out Trial-and-Error Experiments..  The image contains four distinct sections, each with a title and a list of three numbered points. The sections are: "Verify Models," "Validate Features," "Maintain Consistency," and "Carry Out Trial-and-Error Experiments." Each section is represented by a blue box with a white border, and the text is in a sans-serif font. The layout is organized in a grid-like structure, with each section aligned horizontally.

A mind map illustrates the functionality, security, usability, compatibility, and compatibility of Guruggg Bank's website, including features like login, fund transfer, web server, database server, mail server, UI, performance, security, and compatibility..  Dashboard, Bank Interface, Usability Chart, Security Chart, Compatibility Chart

A software testing process flowchart outlines steps for defining and executing test cases, with a decision point to determine suspension criteria..  The image shows a flowchart with a process to define and execute a suspension criteria. The flowchart has three main steps: Define suspension criteria, Execute Test cases, Suspension criteria met?, Suspend the testing, and Developer fix the fail cases? The flowchart uses diamond-shaped decision boxes to indicate the decision-making process. The process is designed to determine if a suspension criteria has been met or not.

A man in a suit and a woman in a beige sweater discuss exit criteria in a meeting room, with a speech bubble indicating 90% total test cases..  The image shows a man and a woman sitting at a table in a meeting room, engaged in a discussion. The man is speaking to the woman, and there is a speech bubble above them. The speech bubble contains text that reads, "Do you confirm the Exit Criteria?" The man is wearing a suit and tie, and the woman is wearing a beige top. The man is pointing at a small device, possibly a tablet or a laptop, while the woman is attentively listening. The room has blinds in the background, and there are chairs visible in the scene.

A four-panel infographic illustrates the importance of resource planning, including budgeting, resource allocation, resource leveling, and resource forecasting..  The image contains four distinct sections, each focusing on different aspects of resource planning. The top left section highlights the importance of resource planning, including maximizing project budget spending, enhancing resource reporting and forecasting, detailed budget analysis, and listing resources. The top right section focuses on creating a resource plan, including estimating resources, listing resources, and constructing a resource schedule. The bottom left section discusses the absence of resource planning, emphasizing that 48% of projects will not be finished on time, 43% of projects will exceed allocated budget, and 31% of projects will not meet their goals. The bottom right section emphasizes resource planning techniques, including resource allocation, resource leveling, and resource forecasting.

A blue project manager, orange build manager, and blue test manager collaborate on a software project, with the build server, test server, and database server connected via blue arrows..  The image displays a flowchart illustrating the process of building a database server. It shows a sequence of steps, including Project Manager, Build Server, Test Server, Build Manager, Database Server, and Test Manager. Each step is represented by a separate box, and arrows connect them to show the flow of the process. The flowchart highlights the steps involved in setting up the database server, including notification to setup the test release, setup on test instance through build scripts, and setup on test current release.

A diagram illustrates a web server for Guru99 Banking Site, connecting four web browsers to a central Internet server, with a globe representing the global web..  The image shows a diagram of a web server setup for a banking site called Guru99. The diagram includes a cloud labeled "Internet," which connects to four web browsers. Each browser is represented by a computer monitor icon, and the four web browsers are connected to the Internet cloud via arrows. The web server is labeled as "Web server for Guru99 Banking Site." The diagram also includes a database server, which is connected to the web server via a blue arrow.

A project timeline for "Making Test Specification" shows milestones, deadlines, and test report completion on August 16, 2023..  The image displays a project timeline with milestones, task names, start and end dates, and progress tracking. It includes a Gantt chart with task names, milestones, start and end dates, and project duration. The chart highlights the completion of the "Making Test Specification" milestone on August 4th, 2023, and the "Test Delivery" milestone on August 18th, 2023.

A flowchart illustrates the process of test case design techniques, including BVA, Equivalence Class Partitioning, Decision Table, State Transition, and Error Guessing..  The image presents a flowchart illustrating the test case design techniques. It includes five distinct sections: Boundary Value Analysis (BVA), Equivalence Class Partitioning, Decision Table, State Transition, and Error Guessing. The BVA section is highlighted in blue, indicating its importance in the testing process. The flowchart visually connects these techniques, showing their sequential relationship and how they contribute to the overall testing process.
A plain white background with a subtle texture..  The image is entirely white with no visible visual elements, text, or diagrams.

A to five steps outline a process for analyzing and designing test cases, including identifying test scenarios, designing test cases, creating test data, creating test data, and mapping test cases to requirements..  The image displays a step-by-step guide on how to analyze and design test cases. It includes five numbered steps: 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Each step provides a clear description of the process, including the purpose of identifying test scenarios, designing test cases, creating test data, and mapping test cases to requirements. The steps are presented in a linear fashion, with each step separated by a purple bar. The steps are visually distinct, making it easy to follow the guide.

A flowchart illustrates a test scenario, with three test cases (Test Document, Test Scenario, Test Case) and a test case (Test Case) connected by a blue arrow..  The image displays a flowchart with three test scenarios. Each scenario is represented by a separate speech bubble, with the first scenario on the left, the second scenario in the middle, and the third scenario on the right. The test scenarios are labeled as "Test Document," "Test Scenario," and "Test Case." The flowchart shows the progression of the test cases, highlighting the different stages and their interconnections.
A table in a webpage header section displays the header information, body content, and footer details for a critical/major/minor test case application..  Header, Body, Footer

A user attempts to log in to a Delta 3-0-ICI-Login functional test case using a browser, but fails due to an invalid username..  The image displays a table with a form titled "Test case template."
